EXPLAINED: Why do we do clinical trials?

A clinical trial is a type of research that tests medical treatments or procedures.

These trials play a key role in helping medical professionals to understand what treatments work most effectively.

Apart from the Queen’s College copy, only two other fragments are known to have survived the flames. Used as binding material in other books, they are now held at the @BeineckeLibrary and @bodleianlibs 📔

Printed at the same time as the first full translation of the Bible into English, all other known copies were burnt alongside his other works in 1546 outside St Paul’s Cathedral as part of Henry VIII’s attempt to stamp out 'heresy'.

This project is the result of global collaboration and support from partners, funders and researchers around the world. We’re grateful for their cooperation and hard work - without them, the #OxfordVaccine wouldn’t have been possible.

With over 23,000 trial volunteers we’ll present a large safety database for independent review. We plan to submit for publication as soon as possible, to make sure #OxfordVaccine data is peer reviewed and available for scrutiny.

In partnership with @AstraZeneca, we’re hoping to supply 3 billion doses of the vaccine and make it available to people around the world by the end of next year. The #OxfordVaccine can be stored at fridge temp & deployed quickly using existing infrastructure.

Today marks an important milestone in the fight against #COVID19. Interim data show the #OxfordVaccine is 70.4% effective, & tests on two dose regimens show that it could be 90%, moving us one step closer to supplying it at low cost around the world>> https://t.co/fnHnKSqftT https://t.co/2KYXPxFNz1

Our 2019 intake saw us admit 3.1% black British students – a new record and an increase on our 2018 2.6% figure. Overall, BAME students, including black students, made  up 22% of the intake in 2019, up from 18% in 2018. (2/3)
To clarify, we’ve seen record figures for both black British students & for BAME students overall. We apologise if this wasn’t clear. (1/3)

@marcus_bernard @ExeterCollegeOx Hello Marcus, It is about positive increases in both, as separate statements - the proportion of talented black British students choosing to study with us is 3.1% compared with 2.6% last year. Separately, 22% of our UG cohort identify as British BAME, an increase from 18%.

@rajacexplains Hi Rajin, More talented black British students are choosing to study with us than ever (3.1% compared with 2.6% last year) and, separately, 22% of our UG cohort identify as British BAME, an increase from 18%.

@drhannahrobbins @victoria_okoye @Pippab3 These signs are a solid foundation for our new initiatives launching in 2020 and beyond, including Opportunity Oxford and our first UG scholarship for academically brilliant, underprivileged black students.
@drhannahrobbins @victoria_okoye @Pippab3 We’re ​encouraged that our expanded access efforts are ​moving in the right direction, but we know there is still much to do.

@drhannahrobbins @victoria_okoye @Pippab3 More talented black British students are choosing to study with us than ever (3.1% compared with 2.6% last year) and, separately, 22% of our UG cohort identify as British BAME, an increase from 18%. The link will take you to a further breakdown on this.
@drhannahrobbins @victoria_okoye @Pippab3 Hi everyone, The above was meant as separate statements and was not a deliberate conflation of two data sets – we apologise if it has come across that way.

The programme will introduce new dishes, new cooking techniques, more sustainable approaches to catering, an updated recipe library, and more, varied, tasty food that everyone can enjoy! 🍵 https://t.co/1Guem4IvwF
The chefs will learn about essential preparation techniques, their importance and their alternatives 🍽 https://t.co/O7HLl19ZUj

Lastly, everyone will learn about catering from across continents, where major ingredients and cooking styles from Africa, the Indian Sub-Continent, East and Central Asia, and South and Central America will be studied 🌏 https://t.co/ducnmzx03E

The next module will cover medically-prescribed diets, and explore how some medical conditions are more prominent in certain ethnic groups. Teams will receive insight into these correlations, so they can respond and adapt to medical declarations when cooking 🍝 https://t.co/xWCrMkYc3b
The chefs will also look at sources of vital nutrients and replacements from common, animal-based ingredients (like yoghurt and honey)🍯 https://t.co/BlUbx8qXbo

They will then learn about ethical eating and why people choose vegan and vegetarian diets. The specifics of catering to ‘meat free’, vegan and vegetarian diets will be discussed and practical advice on meal development will be offered 🥗 https://t.co/t8ZaYZLymo
This covers dishes for Jewish, Islamic, Christian, Hindu, Buddhist, Jain, Rastafarian and atheist/agnostic diners 🍛 https://t.co/Swe22yjEf2

First, the teams will cover catering for religious students, staff and guests, and look at recipes for observant diners that everyone, including those not practicing a religion, can enjoy 🥙 https://t.co/MWC1HUcjHZ

We’ve got an exciting new training programme for our chefs and hospitality teams to make sure everyone can enjoy delicious, nutritious food! The training will cover dietary requirements for religions and beliefs, vegetarianism and veganism, medical diets, and global food 🍲 https://t.co/XISXtgC1kr
